title: Case Study: Rhabdomyolysis in a Young Athlete
clinical_history: A 25-year-old male collegiate football player presented to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe muscle pain, fatigue, and dark-colored urine. He reported participating in an intense training session 3 days prior, which included rigorous exercises and prolonged running in hot weather conditions. He initially attributed his symptoms to delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS) but sought medical attention when his symptoms worsened and he noticed decreased urine output.

nprs.affected_area: Severe muscle pain in the lower extremities, particularly in the quadriceps, hamstrings, and gluteal muscles

aggrevating_factors: Movement, palpation, and stretching of the affected muscles
picture: 24-hour urine output decreased, with dark-colored urine; serum creatine kinase (CK) levels elevated (>10,000 U/L)
easing_factors: Rest, ice application, and pain management with opioids
past_history: No previous history of similar conditions; however, the patient has a history of mild dehydration during intense training sessions
medical_history: Generally healthy, with no chronic medical conditions
medications: Acetaminophen and ibuprofen for pain management; IV fluids and bicarbonate for rhabdomyolysis treatment
personal_history: Lives with teammates; participates in regular intense physical training for football; consumes a high-protein diet
imaging: MRI of lower extremities shows evidence of muscle damage and necrosis; EMG shows myopathic changes
